p: Similar to infections in wildlife populations, large felids including tigers ( Panthera tigris), lions ( Panthera leo), leopards ( Panthera pardus), and jaguars ( Panthera onca) in zoological collections may become infected with CDV. Animals often develop fatal disease with respiratory and gastrointestinal signs followed by neurological manifestation [66], [108]. Possible sources of the virus in zoo outbreaks are small carnivores, such as raccoons or raccoon dogs that may come in contact with captive cats [66], [108]. Usually CDV spreads through aerosol droplets and contact with infected body fluids, but felids may become also infected by predation, e.g. exposure to unvaccinated and infected domestic dogs or other wild susceptible hosts [66], [108].
